title: The trinity of career counselling | Jaishankar Gopalan | TEDxBESC
author: TEDx Talks

key_facts: Sikkim has a government department for capacity building to support student career decisions.
Approximately 4,000 students in Sikkim pass class 10 annually and must make career choices.
Sikkim government identifies job-matching profiles for students and finances those who need to go to other states for skilled employment.
Students in Sikkim repay the government after gaining employment, enabling future cohorts to benefit.
The TEDx platform features a speaker who is a farmer, photographer, musician, and content writer.
One student took an informed career decision in class 8 and became a teacher.
Another student made an informed career choice in class 12 and became a film dress designer.
India needs 50% more doctors and more teachers than currently available.
There are over 4,500 career options available today, creating a complex decision landscape.
Assessment tools exist to identify interests, aptitude, and personality traits relevant to career choices.
A person with a background in engineering completed a master's degree abroad and now works as an application scientist at a major e-commerce company.
Two individuals left banking careers in their mid-30s to start their own ventures.
A national award-winning film dress designer self-financed his education by working in a laundry.
The speaker began career guidance initiatives and coined the acronym POM POM.
POM POM stands for Peace of Mind and Plenty of Money in the context of career decisions.
key_opinions: Taking career decisions by chance leads to inefficient outcomes and wasted resources.
Informed career decisions based on interest, aptitude, and personality lead to peace of mind and financial success.
Parents often impose conventional career paths that may not align with a child’s true potential.
Friends influence career choices through peer pressure and comfort zone dynamics.
Market trends push students toward popular courses regardless of personal fit.
Academics alone are necessary but not sufficient for career success.
The right environment unlocks individual ability and performance.
Career decisions made early reduce the number of life-changing chances needed.
Education becomes an investment when chosen intentionally, not just an expenditure.
Teachers enjoy teaching more when students are engaged and motivated.
Industry benefits when the right person is matched to the right job.
Positive stress is preferable to a rat race in career development.
Self-financing education can be a valuable part of personal growth and skill development.
Career guidance should focus on identifying relevant skills before selecting courses.
Choosing a career based on passion leads to long-term satisfaction and achievement.
